metadata.sermon_start_end: THIS IS another sermon in a sequence from Isaiah 28. I admit to being fascinated by this text. All my life I have been gripped by the problem of evil and suffering. These are the kinds of questions that disturb me and many other Christians [...] All this also comes from the Lord almighty, wonderful in counsel and magnificent in wisdom. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on Isaiah 28:21, yet it struggles to identify what is unique to this text that cannot be found elsewhere. It quickly pivots to a general theological problem (theodicy) and Luther's systematic categories rather than the specific prophetic context of the Ephraimite/Judahite crisis.
quotes: The prophet’s words have a wider application. More and more, when I read and hear about awful things happening, I find myself thinking in the terms that Isaiah used.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the specific historical 'strangeness' of God acting against His own people in Isaiah 28, rather than treating the text as a springboard for a general discussion on suffering.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is minimal. While the preacher mentions Isaiah's status and the Assyrian threat, there is no engagement with the original languages or the specific structure of the Hebrew poetry. The 'strange work' is interpreted through Luther's 16th-century dogmatics rather than 8th-century BCE Israelite theology.
quotes: Martin Luther drew upon this text to develop the idea that God has proper work (opus proprium) and alien work (opus alienum).
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exposition by explaining the significance of Mount Perazim and Gibeon mentioned in verse 21 to show how God’s 'strange' work was previously directed at enemies, but is now directed at His people.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete, touching on the Civil War, airplane crashes, and university chapel politics. However, it risks becoming a series of 'general truths' about God's sovereignty rather than a specific application of the Word to the hearer's spiritual state.
quotes: This is a familiar subject for us who are Southerners. For a hundred years or more, Southerners were preoccupied with having lost the Civil War.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond historical anecdotes to the contemporary 'covenant with death' (v. 15) that the modern hearer might be making.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured more like a thematic lecture than a mixed movement. The text is used to validate a theological concept (the two hands of God), and then examples are layered on top. The hearer is not 'expounded' through the text so much as through the examples.
quotes: I’m speaking specifically of these verses... God’s strange work, his alien work — these are terms that have proven to be theologically fruitful.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Instead of using the text to explain a concept, use the movement of the text to confront the hearer's current reality.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present in the form of suffering and the 'alien work' of judgment. Redemption is found in the 'right hand' of God. However, the gratitude part is somewhat replaced by a stoic 'testimony' of trust rather than a Spirit-awakened response to grace.
quotes: I believe it is better to be in God’s left hand than in the devil’s right.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'alien work' to the necessity of the 'proper work' of redemption to avoid a purely objective view of God's sovereignty.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon leans heavily toward a deterministic view of God's 'point of view' where even enemies are 'used in God's plan.' This weakens the urgency of the 'two ways' and human responsibility. The possibility of being lost is neutralized by the idea that 'both hands can be trusted.'
quotes: And God was going to use the Assyrians in his plan whether they knew of it or not. Think of that — what an honor to be used in God’s plan without even knowing about it!
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Reintroduce the prophetic warning of the 'narrow way.' If both hands are equally 'trustworthy' without the call to repentance, the seriousness of the 'broad way' to destruction disappears.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as a 'Messianic prophecy' and a name omitted from prayers, but He is not the telos of the sermon. The sermon ends on 'God almighty' rather than the specific revelation of God in Christ as the resolution of the 'strange work.'
quotes: It is no accident that Isaiah is the prophet of the Christmas season — his matchless Messianic prophecies are among the glories of the Christian tradition.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how the 'strange work' of judgment and the 'proper work' of grace converge specifically in the Cross of Christ.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14 minutes (1450 words), the sermon fails Dekker's requirement of 20 minutes. It lacks the 'breadth' needed for 'depth,' specifically in the exegetical and dogmatic sections.
quotes: It isn’t possible in a short sermon like this to go into all the vexed issues and distressing convolutions.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical foundation and the dogmatic implications of the 'two natures' in relation to God's 'two hands' to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its brevity and its tendency to treat the biblical text as a thematic illustration for theodicy rather than a unique proclamatory word. It lacks rigorous exegetical depth and fails to maintain the tension of the 'two ways,' opting instead for a generalized trust in divine sovereignty. While the application is concrete, it is more sociological/historical than strictly scriptural.
strengths: Concrete application: Uses historical and contemporary examples (Civil War, chapel politics) to ground the theological problem.
Theological background: Correctly identifies the Lutheran distinction of opus proprium and opus alienum as a framework for Isaiah 28.
weaknesses: Insufficient length: At 14 minutes, it lacks the necessary breadth for homiletical depth.
Weak Christology: Christ is a peripheral theme rather than the telos of the proclamation.
Lack of specific exegesis: Fails to explain what Isaiah 28 says that cannot be found elsewhere in Scripture.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an 'adequate' theological speech, but it is not a 'sermon' in the full sense of Dekker's definition. It lacks the required length, the specific exegetical rigor, and the urgent call to the 'two ways' that characterizes true proclamation.
